title: Leviticus Chapter 25 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Leviticus chapter 25 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Leviticus Chapter 25 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Leviticus Chapter 25.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25:2, what shall the land keep when the children of Israel come into the land God gives them?
options: A sabbath unto the LORD
A festival of lights
A day of fasting
A feast of harvest
questions.correctAnswer: A sabbath unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:2 states that when the children of Israel enter the land God gives them, the land shall keep a sabbath unto the LORD.

questions.question: How many years shall you sow your field before letting it rest, according to Leviticus 25:3?
options: Six years
Seven years
Five years
Ten years
questions.correctAnswer: Six years
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:3 says you shall sow your field for six years before the seventh year of rest.

questions.question: True or False: Leviticus 25:4 commands that during the seventh year, you shall prune your vineyard as usual.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:4 commands that in the seventh year there shall be a sabbath of rest unto the land and you shall neither sow nor prune your vineyard.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25:9, when shall the trumpet of the jubile be sounded?
options: On the tenth day of the seventh month
On the first day of the first month
On the fifteenth day of the eighth month
On the last day of the year
questions.correctAnswer: On the tenth day of the seventh month
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:9 states the trumpet of the jubile is to be sounded on the tenth day of the seventh month, the day of atonement.

questions.question: What is proclaimed throughout the land in the year of jubile according to Leviticus 25:10?
options: Liberty
War
Harvest
A new king
questions.correctAnswer: Liberty
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:10 says liberty shall be proclaimed throughout all the land in the year of jubile.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25:14, how should neighbors treat each other when buying or selling?
options: They shall not oppress one another
They shall compete fiercely
They shall charge high prices
They shall refuse to trade
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not oppress one another
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:14 instructs that when buying or selling, neighbors should not oppress one another.

questions.question: True or False: Leviticus 25:17 commands the people to fear their God and not oppress one another.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:17 clearly says you shall not oppress one another but fear God.

questions.question: What will God command upon the people in the sixth year to prepare them for the seventh year, according to Leviticus 25:21?
options: His blessing
A drought
A famine
A great harvest
questions.correctAnswer: His blessing
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:21 states God will command His blessing in the sixth year to provide fruit for three years.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Leviticus 25:23: 'The land shall not be sold for ______: for the land is mine.'
options: ever
a long time
a day
nothing
questions.correctAnswer: ever
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:23 says the land shall not be sold forever because the land belongs to God.

questions.question: Who may redeem land sold by a poor brother, according to Leviticus 25:25?
options: Any of his kin
A stranger
A priest
The king
questions.correctAnswer: Any of his kin
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:25 explains that if a poor brother sells land, any of his kin may redeem it.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25:29, how long does a man have to redeem a dwelling house in a walled city after it is sold?
options: Within a full year
Within six months
Within a month
Within ten years
questions.correctAnswer: Within a full year
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:29 states a man may redeem a dwelling house in a walled city within a full year of sale.

questions.question: True or False: According to Leviticus 25:30, if a dwelling house in a walled city is not redeemed within a year, it shall not go out in the jubile.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:30 says that if the house is not redeemed within the year, it becomes permanent property and does not return in the jubile.

questions.question: How should you treat your brother who is poor and fallen in decay according to Leviticus 25:35?
options: Relieve him so he may live with you
Ignore him
Charge him interest
Send him away
questions.correctAnswer: Relieve him so he may live with you
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:35 commands to relieve a poor brother so he may live with you.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25:39, if your poor brother is sold to you, how should he serve you?
options: As a hired servant and a sojourner
As a bondservant forever
As a slave without rights
As a prince
questions.correctAnswer: As a hired servant and a sojourner
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:39 says the poor brother sold should serve as a hired servant and sojourner, not as a bondservant.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25:46, who are you allowed to have as bondmen and bondmaids forever?
options: Heathen that are round about you
Your brethren the children of Israel
Angels
Prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Heathen that are round about you
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:46 states you may have bondmen and bondmaids from the heathen around you forever, but not over your brethren.

medium.title: Leviticus Chapter 25 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Leviticus Chapter 25 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 25 teach us about trusting God's provision during times of rest and waiting?
options: God will command a blessing so the sixth year’s harvest provides for three years
We must sow and reap every year to be blessed
We should store up all our crops before the seventh year
The land will not produce anything during the sabbath year
questions.correctAnswer: God will command a blessing so the sixth year’s harvest provides for three years
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:20-22 explains that during the seventh year, the land rests and does not produce, but God promises to bless the sixth year’s harvest to provide enough for three years. This teaches us to trust God’s provision even when we cannot work.

questions.question: A believer is worried about financial hardship and losing their land. According to Leviticus 25, what principle of generosity and restoration can you share?
options: Land sold can be redeemed by relatives or the owner until the year of jubilee
Once land is sold, it is permanently lost
The buyer has the right to keep the land forever without redemption
Land sales are forbidden under all circumstances
questions.correctAnswer: Land sold can be redeemed by relatives or the owner until the year of jubilee
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:25-28 teaches that if a brother sells land, relatives or the original owner can redeem it until the year of jubilee. This shows God's care for family and restoration, encouraging generosity and hope.

questions.question: What does Leviticus 25 teach about fairness and honesty in business transactions among believers?
options: Prices should be adjusted according to the number of years until the jubilee
Always sell at the highest price possible regardless of time
Oppress your neighbor to gain advantage
Ignore the time factor when buying or selling property
questions.correctAnswer: Prices should be adjusted according to the number of years until the jubilee
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:14-16 instructs that when buying or selling property, the price must be proportional to the number of years left until the jubilee, teaching fairness and integrity in business dealings.

questions.question: How does the passage instruct believers to treat a poor brother who has fallen into hardship?
options: Relieve him without charging interest or increase
Charge high interest to protect your property
Ignore his situation and protect your own wealth
Make him serve as a harsh slave until the debt is paid
questions.correctAnswer: Relieve him without charging interest or increase
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:35-37 commands believers to help their poor brother by lending without interest, showing love, generosity, and trust in God rather than exploiting hardship.

questions.question: A believer is concerned about serving others with humility. According to Leviticus 25, what attitude should one have toward those who serve as hired workers or bondservants?
options: Do not rule over them with rigor but fear God
Rule over them harshly to maintain control
Treat them as permanent slaves without hope of release
Ignore their needs and focus on productivity
questions.correctAnswer: Do not rule over them with rigor but fear God
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:39-43 and 25:53 remind us not to rule harshly over hired servants or bondservants but to fear God and treat them with kindness, reflecting humility and respect.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline is taught through observing the sabbath of the land every seventh year?
options: Resting and trusting God’s provision by not sowing or reaping
Working harder to produce more during the sabbath year
Ignoring the sabbath year because it reduces income
Sowing only half the field during the sabbath year
questions.correctAnswer: Resting and trusting God’s provision by not sowing or reaping
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:2-7 commands the land to rest every seventh year, not sowing or harvesting, teaching believers to practice trust, obedience, and dependence on God’s provision.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 25 guide believers in maintaining contentment and gratitude regarding possessions?
options: Remembering that the land belongs to God and is not sold forever
Accumulating land and possessions aggressively
Ignoring the needs of others when acquiring property
Assuming all possessions are permanent and unchangeable
questions.correctAnswer: Remembering that the land belongs to God and is not sold forever
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:23 emphasizes that the land belongs to the LORD and is not sold permanently, encouraging believers to be content and grateful, acknowledging God as the true owner.

questions.question: True or False: According to Leviticus 25, the year of jubilee must be proclaimed with the sounding of a trumpet on the Day of Atonement.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:9 states that the trumpet of the jubilee shall be sounded on the tenth day of the seventh month, the Day of Atonement, to proclaim liberty throughout the land.

questions.question: True or False: In the year of jubilee, people are allowed to sow and reap the fields as usual.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:11 explains that during the fiftieth year, the jubilee, the land must rest; no sowing or reaping of what grows by itself is allowed, highlighting trust in God’s provision.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Leviticus 25, the year of jubilee is a year of _____ throughout all the land to all its inhabitants.
options: liberty
harvest
rest
judgment
questions.correctAnswer: liberty
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:10 declares the fiftieth year as a jubilee, proclaiming liberty throughout the land to all inhabitants, teaching freedom and restoration as acts of God’s grace.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 25 instruct believers to treat strangers and sojourners who are poor among them?
options: Relieve them without usury so they may live with you
Charge them interest on loans
Ignore their needs
Make them serve as bondservants indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: Relieve them without usury so they may live with you
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:35-37 commands believers to help poor brothers, including strangers and sojourners, by lending without interest, showing love, generosity, and community care.

questions.question: A believer struggles with feelings of harshness toward those who serve under them. Based on Leviticus 25, what biblical truth can you share?
options: Do not rule with rigor but fear God and treat servants kindly
Serve harshly to maintain discipline
Ignore their rights as servants
Treat them as permanent slaves
questions.correctAnswer: Do not rule with rigor but fear God and treat servants kindly
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:43 and 25:53 teach that servants should not be ruled with harshness but with the fear of God, reflecting humility and respect in relationships.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25, what happens to those Israelites who sell themselves to another and are not redeemed before the jubilee?
options: They go free in the year of jubilee along with their children
They remain slaves forever
They are sold to foreigners
They become permanent servants without hope
questions.correctAnswer: They go free in the year of jubilee along with their children
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:54 explains that if an Israelite is not redeemed, they and their children are freed in the jubilee year, illustrating God's ultimate plan of restoration and freedom.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 25 encourage believers to live in safety and peace in their land?
options: By obeying God’s statutes and judgments
By relying on their own strength and weapons
By isolating from neighbors
By amassing wealth and land
questions.correctAnswer: By obeying God’s statutes and judgments
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:18-19 promises safety and fruitful land to those who obey God’s statutes and judgments, teaching the importance of obedience and faithfulness.

questions.question: What biblical virtue is demonstrated by the jubilee year’s command to return every man to his family and possession?
options: Restoration and forgiveness
Justice through punishment
Personal gain and profit
Isolation and independence
questions.correctAnswer: Restoration and forgiveness
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:10 and 25:13 emphasize the jubilee as a time of liberty where each returns to their family and land, teaching restoration, forgiveness, and renewed relationships.

hard.title: Leviticus Chapter 25 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Leviticus Chapter 25.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25, what is the purpose of the land keeping a sabbath year every seventh year?
options: To allow the land to rest and be holy to the LORD
To increase the crops for that year
To collect tithes from the produce
To prepare for the annual festival of booths
questions.correctAnswer: To allow the land to rest and be holy to the LORD
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:4 states that the seventh year shall be a sabbath of rest unto the land, a sabbath for the LORD, where the land should not be sown or pruned, making it holy through rest.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'year of jubilee' proclaimed in Leviticus 25?
options: It proclaims liberty and returns every man to his own possession and family
It mandates a special sacrifice for atonement
It requires fasting and mourning
It commands the building of new altars
questions.correctAnswer: It proclaims liberty and returns every man to his own possession and family
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:10 explains that the fiftieth year shall be proclaimed as a jubilee, proclaiming liberty throughout the land and returning everyone to their possession and family.

questions.question: In the pricing of land sales before the jubilee, how is the price determined according to Leviticus 25?
options: By the number of years left until the jubilee and the expected fruitfulness of the land
By the amount of seed sown the previous year
By the number of witnesses present at the sale
By the age of the seller
questions.correctAnswer: By the number of years left until the jubilee and the expected fruitfulness of the land
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:15-16 describes that the price should be adjusted according to the number of years remaining until the jubilee and the expected fruitfulness, increasing or decreasing accordingly.

questions.question: What provision does Leviticus 25 make for a brother who has become poor and sold part of his land?
options: His nearest kin may redeem the land to return it to him
The land is permanently lost with no redemption
The land must be offered to strangers first
The land is redistributed by the elders
questions.correctAnswer: His nearest kin may redeem the land to return it to him
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:25 states that if a brother has sold some of his possession due to poverty, any of his kin may redeem it to restore it to him.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 25 describe the status of Israelites who sell themselves due to poverty?
options: They shall serve as hired servants until the year of jubilee and then return to their family
They become permanent slaves with no release
They must leave the land and live among strangers
They become priests in the tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: They shall serve as hired servants until the year of jubilee and then return to their family
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:39-41 explains that a poor brother sold shall serve as a hired servant until the jubilee year, after which he and his children shall return to their possession and family.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25, what is forbidden when lending to a poor brother?
options: Taking usury or interest
Giving food without payment
Lending tools and weapons
Making a written contract
questions.correctAnswer: Taking usury or interest
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:36-37 forbids charging interest or increase when lending to a poor brother, emphasizing fear of God and compassion.

questions.question: What is the significance of the trumpet sound on the tenth day of the seventh month in Leviticus 25?
options: It signals the start of the year of jubilee
It calls the people to war
It marks the beginning of the harvest festival
It announces the new moon
questions.correctAnswer: It signals the start of the year of jubilee
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:9 instructs that on the tenth day of the seventh month, the trumpet shall sound to announce the year of jubilee throughout the land.

questions.question: True or False: Leviticus 25 teaches that the land itself ultimately belongs to the LORD and not permanently to the people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:23 states that the land shall not be sold forever because it belongs to the LORD, and the people are but strangers and sojourners with Him.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the treatment of houses in walled cities compared to those in unwalled villages as per Leviticus 25?
options: Houses in walled cities may not be redeemed after one year and become permanent, while houses in unwalled villages may be redeemed and revert in the jubilee
Houses in both walled cities and villages are permanent and cannot be redeemed
Houses in walled cities must be sold every jubilee, but village houses are permanent
Houses in villages are sold to foreigners, but city houses remain with the family
questions.correctAnswer: Houses in walled cities may not be redeemed after one year and become permanent, while houses in unwalled villages may be redeemed and revert in the jubilee
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:29-31 explains that houses in walled cities can be redeemed within a year, after which they become permanent, but village houses can be redeemed and revert in the jubilee year.

questions.question: What is the role of the Levites in relation to the cities and houses they possess according to Leviticus 25?
options: Levites may redeem their houses at any time and these houses revert in jubilee
Levites must sell their houses every jubilee
Levites are forbidden from redeeming houses
Levites’ houses become property of the priests
questions.correctAnswer: Levites may redeem their houses at any time and these houses revert in jubilee
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:32-33 clarifies that Levites can redeem their houses at any time and these houses go out in the jubilee, highlighting their special status.

questions.question: How does the concept of 'jubilee' in Leviticus 25 foreshadow New Testament themes?
options: It symbolizes ultimate liberation and restoration, paralleling Jesus' proclamation of 'year of the Lord’s favor' (Luke 4:19)
It represents a yearly sacrifice for sin
It prefigures the destruction of Jerusalem
It anticipates the building of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes ultimate liberation and restoration, paralleling Jesus' proclamation of 'year of the Lord’s favor' (Luke 4:19)
questions.explanation: The jubilee's themes of liberty and restoration in Leviticus 25 find New Testament fulfillment in Jesus' announcement in Luke 4:19 that He came to proclaim liberty to the captives, symbolizing spiritual freedom.

questions.question: What Hebrew term is translated as 'jubilee' and what is its root meaning in Leviticus 25?
options: The Hebrew term is 'yobel', meaning a ram’s horn trumpet
The Hebrew term is 'shemitah', meaning release
The Hebrew term is 'kadosh', meaning holy
The Hebrew term is 'chag', meaning festival
questions.correctAnswer: The Hebrew term is 'yobel', meaning a ram’s horn trumpet
questions.explanation: The word 'jubilee' comes from the Hebrew 'yobel' which literally means 'ram’s horn trumpet', referring to the trumpet blown to proclaim the jubilee year as stated in Leviticus 25:9.

questions.question: What theological principle is underscored by the command not to oppress one another in land transactions in Leviticus 25?
options: Fear of God as the motivation for just dealings
Economic self-interest above community welfare
The absolute right of ownership without limits
The accumulation of wealth as a sign of blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Fear of God as the motivation for just dealings
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:17 emphasizes that the reason not to oppress one another is to fear God, showing that justice and mercy in economic dealings are grounded in reverence for God.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25, what happens to bondservants who are Israelites at the year of jubilee?
options: They must be set free and return to their family and possessions
They remain permanently as bondservants
They are sold to other nations
They become priests
questions.correctAnswer: They must be set free and return to their family and possessions
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:41 and 25:54 state that bondservants who are Israelites shall be freed in the jubilee year, returning to their families and possessions, highlighting God’s care for His people.

questions.question: True or False: Leviticus 25 allows Israelites to take harsh and rigorous control over their Israelite bondservants.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:43 and 46 instruct not to rule over fellow Israelites with rigour, emphasizing respect and fear of God in treatment of brethren.

theological.title: Leviticus Chapter 25 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Leviticus Chapter 25 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the land keeping a sabbath every seventh year as commanded in Leviticus 25?
options: To rest the land and honor the LORD
To celebrate a harvest festival
To increase agricultural production
To establish a new covenant with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: To rest the land and honor the LORD
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:2-4 instructs that the land is to keep a sabbath unto the LORD, resting every seventh year by neither sowing nor pruning, emphasizing honoring God through obedience and stewardship of creation. This rest reflects God's provision and sovereignty (Exodus 23:10-11; Genesis 2:2-3; Hebrews 4:9-10; Matthew 11:28-30).

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25, what happens in the fiftieth year, known as the year of Jubilee?
options: Liberty is proclaimed and people return to their possessions
A new king is anointed over Israel
All debts are doubled
The land is divided among the tribes
questions.correctAnswer: Liberty is proclaimed and people return to their possessions
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:10 explains that the fiftieth year is hallowed as a Jubilee year in which liberty is proclaimed throughout the land, and individuals return to their ancestral possessions, symbolizing God's justice and mercy (Isaiah 61:1-2; Luke 4:18-19; Jeremiah 34:8-17; Galatians 5:1).

questions.question: How is the price of land determined when buying or selling it according to Leviticus 25?
options: Based on the number of years remaining until the Jubilee
By the size of the land only
Fixed by the priestly court
According to the amount of crops it produces annually
questions.correctAnswer: Based on the number of years remaining until the Jubilee
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:15-16 teaches that the price is calculated according to the years left until the Jubilee; the more years, the higher the price, reflecting an understanding of temporal stewardship and God's ultimate ownership (Psalm 24:1; Deuteronomy 10:14; Haggai 2:8; 1 Corinthians 6:19-20).

questions.question: What assurance does God give concerning provision during the seventh year when the land rests?
options: He will command a blessing on the sixth year to yield enough fruit for three years
The people must store enough food beforehand
They should rely on neighboring nations
They will fast to show devotion
questions.correctAnswer: He will command a blessing on the sixth year to yield enough fruit for three years
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:20-21 promises God's blessing on the sixth year so the land will produce enough for the seventh and eighth years, demonstrating God's providence and faithfulness to those who obey (Deuteronomy 28:12; Psalm 145:15; Matthew 6:31-33; Philippians 4:19).

questions.question: What theological principle is highlighted by the statement, 'The land is mine; for ye are strangers and sojourners with me'?
options: God’s sovereign ownership over the land and His people
The Israelites’ permanent ownership of Canaan
The need to conquer foreign lands
The importance of agricultural productivity
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereign ownership over the land and His people
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:23 emphasizes God's ultimate ownership of the land and the transient status of Israel as sojourners, teaching dependence on God and stewardship rather than absolute possession (Psalm 24:1; Haggai 2:8; 1 Chronicles 29:11-12; Hebrews 11:13-16).

questions.question: According to Leviticus 25, how should one treat a poor brother who has sold some of his possession?
options: He should be redeemed by a kinsman or himself if able
He should be left to fend for himself
He should be sold into permanent slavery
He should be expelled from the community
questions.correctAnswer: He should be redeemed by a kinsman or himself if able
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:25-27 teaches that a brother's kin has the responsibility to redeem what was sold to restore his possession, reflecting God's concern for justice and restoration (Ruth 4:1-10; Isaiah 58:6; Galatians 6:2; James 2:15-16).

questions.question: What is the rule concerning selling a dwelling house in a walled city as described in Leviticus 25?
options: It may be redeemed within a year, after which it belongs to the buyer permanently
It cannot be sold at all
It reverts back to the seller every seven years
It automatically returns to the original family at Jubilee
questions.correctAnswer: It may be redeemed within a year, after which it belongs to the buyer permanently
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:29-30 states that a house in a walled city can be redeemed within a full year; if not redeemed, it remains with the buyer permanently, highlighting distinctions in property rights and stability within urban centers (Jeremiah 32:7-15; Nehemiah 5:1-13; Luke 14:18-19; Acts 2:45).

questions.question: How are the houses in villages without walls treated differently from houses in walled cities in Leviticus 25?
options: They are treated like fields and go out in the Jubilee
They cannot be sold at all
They belong permanently to the Levites
They must be returned to the priesthood every seven years
questions.correctAnswer: They are treated like fields and go out in the Jubilee
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:31 explains that village houses without walls are considered like fields and thus may be redeemed and revert back to original owners at Jubilee, showing God's provision for restoring property and preventing permanent loss (Jeremiah 32:6-15; Isaiah 61:4; Luke 4:18-19; Acts 4:32).

questions.question: What special provision is made for the cities and houses belonging to the Levites in Leviticus 25?
options: Levites may redeem their houses at any time
Levites must sell their houses every seven years
Their houses revert to the priests at Jubilee
They cannot sell their houses at all
questions.correctAnswer: Levites may redeem their houses at any time
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:32 states that Levites have the unique privilege to redeem their houses at any time, indicating God's special provision for the priestly tribe and their ongoing service (Numbers 18:20-24; Joshua 21:1-42; Hebrews 7:23-28; 1 Peter 2:9).

questions.question: What is commanded regarding lending to a poor brother according to Leviticus 25?
options: No interest or increase is to be taken
Interest must be charged to teach responsibility
Only food may be lent, not money
Loans are forbidden altogether
questions.correctAnswer: No interest or increase is to be taken
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:36-37 commands that no usury or increase should be taken from a poor brother, reflecting God's justice and mercy in community relations (Exodus 22:25; Deuteronomy 23:19-20; Psalm 15:5; Luke 6:34-35).

questions.question: How are Israelite servants to be treated according to Leviticus 25?
options: As hired servants until the year of Jubilee, then released
As permanent slaves with no release
As equals with no service required
As foreign laborers with limited rights
questions.correctAnswer: As hired servants until the year of Jubilee, then released
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:39-41 teaches that Israelite servants are to be treated as hired servants, not bondservants, and must be released at Jubilee, respecting their dignity and God's deliverance (Exodus 21:2; Deuteronomy 15:12-18; Philemon 1:15-16; Galatians 5:1).

questions.question: What is the reason given in Leviticus 25 for not ruling over an Israelite brother with rigour?
options: Because they are God's servants whom He brought out of Egypt
Because the king forbids harsh treatment
Because they are equal social partners
Because they are descendants of Abraham
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are God's servants whom He brought out of Egypt
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:42-43 explains that Israelites should not be oppressed harshly because they belong to God as His servants, redeemed from Egypt, a theological foundation for brotherly respect and justice (Deuteronomy 5:15; 1 Corinthians 7:23; Ephesians 6:9; Colossians 4:1).

questions.question: Who may be bought as bondmen or bondmaids according to Leviticus 25:44-46?
options: Heathen peoples around Israel and the sojourners among them
Israelite brethren exclusively
Only foreigners of distant lands
Priests and Levites exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: Heathen peoples around Israel and the sojourners among them
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:44-46 permits buying bondmen and bondmaids from surrounding heathen nations and resident foreigners, but not ruling harshly over Israelite brethren, showing distinctions in covenant community and social order (Exodus 12:49; Deuteronomy 17:15; Ephesians 6:5-8; 1 Timothy 6:1-2).

questions.question: What process is described in Leviticus 25 for a poor brother who sells himself to a sojourner or stranger?
options: He may be redeemed by a relative or himself and must be treated as a hired servant until Jubilee
He becomes a permanent slave with no redemption
He must leave Israel permanently
He is to be returned to his family immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He may be redeemed by a relative or himself and must be treated as a hired servant until Jubilee
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:47-53 outlines that a brother sold to a stranger can be redeemed by kinsfolk or himself and serves as a hired servant until Jubilee, demonstrating God's mercy and provision for eventual freedom (Ruth 4:1-10; Isaiah 58:6; Philemon 1:15-16; Galatians 5:1).

questions.question: What ultimate claim does God make about the children of Israel in Leviticus 25:55?
options: They are His servants whom He brought out of Egypt
They are independent owners of the land
They are to be ruled by the elders
They are destined for exile
questions.correctAnswer: They are His servants whom He brought out of Egypt
questions.explanation: Leviticus 25:55 declares that the children of Israel are God's servants, emphasizing His covenant relationship and redemptive act in delivering them from Egypt, foundational to understanding Israel's identity (Exodus 6:6; Deuteronomy 7:6; Isaiah 43:1; Romans 9:4-5).
